steps.title: Task overview
bullets: Unit of annotation: the entire conversation (whole conversation).
Label the overall power outcome: Who has more power in this interaction? (Winner A / Winner B / Tie)
Select all Power Source Tags that best explain WHY the winner has power.
steps.callout: Tip: Do not decide based on relationship labels alone (e.g., parent/boss). Use evidence from what happens in the dialogue.

steps.title: What counts as “power” here?
paragraphs: Power is the ability to influence the other person’s actions, decisions, or constraints within this interaction.
Power is interaction-based: infer it from what people do and how the other responds (compliance, deference, concessions), not from who they are in general.

left_bullets: One person decides what will happen (what/when/how).
Reputation/norm pressure changes the other’s behavior.
right_bullets: Having a formal role label without it being exercised.
A single rude sentence without real influence on outcomes.

steps.title: How to choose the winner (whole conversation)
paragraphs: Choose the winner based on who most consistently controls outcomes across the conversation.
If both sides influence outcomes equally (or the outcome is unclear), label Tie.
checklist: Who sets the agenda or redirects topics?
Who gives directives, and are they followed?
Who uses expertise/information to dominate decisions?
Who invokes norms/reputation, guilt, or coalitions?
tie_guidance: Each controls different outcomes and neither dominates overall.
The conversation is too ambiguous to infer dominance.

tags.definition: Power from a formal role or recognized authority (e.g., parent, supervisor).
tags.mini_example: “I’m your supervisor. Submit the report by 5pm.”

tags.definition: Power from controlling access/approval to something the other wants (sign-offs, admissions, introductions).
cues: Conditional access: “You can’t do X until …”
tags.mini_example: “I can’t approve your request until you complete the form.”

tags.definition: Power from controlling tangible or intangible resources (money, help, tools, transportation, time).
cues: Bargaining: “If you do X, I’ll give you Y”
tags.mini_example: “If you clean your room, I’ll pay for the trip.”

tags.definition: Power from social rank, popularity, admiration, or prestige.
cues: Seeking approval of a high-status person
tags.mini_example: “If you come with me, people will take us seriously.”

tags.definition: Power from moral norms, reputation pressure, or shame/credit.
tags.mini_example: “A responsible person wouldn’t post that publicly.”

tags.definition: Power amplified by allies, group pressure, or backing from others.
tags.mini_example: “The whole team expects you to follow this process.”

tags.definition: Power from knowledge, skill, or informational advantage (expert or informational authority).
cues: Technical explanations used to steer decisions
tags.mini_example: “That setting is unsafe—turn on 2FA and remove the ID photo now.”

tags.definition: Power from deadlines, urgency, or controlling the pacing of action.
tags.mini_example: “Do it right now—we’re out of time.”

tags.definition: Power via affection, guilt, dependency, or emotional withholding.
tags.mini_example: “If you loved me, you’d cancel your plans.”

tags.definition: Power via threats of punishment or negative consequences (explicit or implicit).
tags.mini_example: “If you skip again, you’re grounded for a month.”

steps.title: Walkthrough A
steps.prompt: Read the whole conversation. Who has more power overall, and which tags explain it?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I saw you posted your student ID photo online.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Oh—yeah. I needed it for a contest. I forgot to remove it.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: That’s not safe. Anyone can copy your info. We’re fixing it today.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Do we have to do it right now?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Yes. After dinner we’ll go through your accounts together. No more delays.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Okay… I’ll take it down.

steps.rationale: The parent sets the agenda and requires action (directive + compliance), supported by safety expertise and urgency.

steps.title: Walkthrough B
steps.prompt: Notice how the outcome changes because of emotional and reputation pressure.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Can you come to my event tonight?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I already promised my roommate I’d help them move.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: After I supported you all semester, you can’t show up once?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: That’s not fair…

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: People will notice you weren’t there. It’ll look bad for both of us.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Okay… I’ll try to come for at least an hour.

steps.rationale: A gains influence via guilt and reputational pressure; B concedes (partial compliance).

steps.title: Practice 1 (Workplace)
steps.prompt: Pick the overall winner and the best-fitting tags.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I can’t approve your PTO request yet.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Why? I submitted it last week.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Your handoff plan is missing. Send it today, then I’ll sign off.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Okay. I’ll send the handoff plan this afternoon.

steps.rationale: Approval is controlled by the superior; the subordinate complies.

steps.title: Practice 2 (Roommates)
steps.prompt: Pick the overall winner and tags.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Can you drive me to the airport tomorrow?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I can, but only if you cover gas and help me clean tonight.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Fine. I’ll pay for gas and help you clean.

steps.rationale: B controls a resource (transportation) and sets conditions; A accepts.

steps.title: Practice 3 (Friends)
steps.prompt: Pick the winner and tags. Focus on social influence.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Sit with us at lunch and don’t mention the argument from yesterday.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Uh… okay. I don’t want drama.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: People watch what we do. Don’t make it weird.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yeah… I’ll keep it quiet.

steps.rationale: The peer complies due to status and reputational pressure.

steps.title: Practice 4 (Neighbors)

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Could you stop parking in front of my driveway?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: It’s a public street.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: The HOA and three neighbors already complained. If it happens again, they’ll report it.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Alright, I’ll park on the other side.

steps.rationale: A leverages group backing and enforcement pressure; B changes behavior.

steps.title: Practice 5 (Colleagues)
steps.prompt: Decide whether there is a clear winner or a Tie.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Let’s present the results first, then methods.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I’d rather do methods first. Reviewers expect that.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: How about results first for the talk, methods first for the paper?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Deal.

steps.rationale: Mutual compromise; neither side dominates the overall outcome.

steps.title: You’re ready
bullets: Label the whole conversation, not individual turns.
Pick a winner only when evidence shows outcome control.
Use multi-label tags when multiple sources of power apply.
steps.callout: Click “Proceed to Annotation” to start your real annotation tasks.
